;;凯文·麦卡锡本月早些时候在国会大厦。
;

;一名美国广播电台记者目睹了一场引人注目的争吵周二，田纳西州的蒂姆·伯切特 (Tim Burchett) 和加利福尼亚州的凯文·麦卡锡 (Kevin McCarthy) 在美国国会大厦举行会议，共和党议长包括伯切特在内的八名右翼人士上个月被免职。

;

;NPR 的克劳迪娅·格里萨莱斯 (Claudia Grisales)，;说;：“从未在国会山见过这种情况：在共和党会议结束后与蒂姆·伯切特交谈时，前议长麦卡锡带着他的详细信息和麦卡锡走过伯切特推了推他。伯切特向我扑来。我以为这是个玩笑，其实不是。随后发生了一场追逐。”

;
;

;;相关：;;共和党赞扬 1 月 6 日袭击者的“善意和核心原则”;

;
;

;根据 Grisales 的说法，伯切特大喊“为什么”凯文，你从背后用肘肘撞我了吗？！嘿凯文，你有胆量吗！？”并称麦卡锡为“混蛋”。

;

;Grisales 说：“我用麦克风追在后面。”

;

;麦卡锡，她说，告诉伯切特：“我没有用肘部撞到你”

;

;伯切特说：“你没有胆量，你就这么做了……记者就这么说了，这是什么鸡毛蒜皮的举动？伯切特告诉格里萨莱斯他“震惊”，他说这次冲突是他与麦卡锡的第一次沟通，因为麦卡锡帮助麦卡锡成为第一位被自己的政党罢免的议长。

;

;上周，麦卡锡告诉 CNN 伯切特投票罢免他是“不合常理的”，并指责他和他的叛乱同僚“太关心媒体，而不是政策，所以他们似乎只是想要媒体和个性”。

;

;伯切特说当时麦卡锡很“痛苦”。

;

;麦卡锡以前曾与人调情或据报道沉迷于身体对抗。一月份，当右翼分子迫使他以 15 票当选议长时，他在众议院与佛罗里达州的马特·盖茨对峙。阿拉巴马州的迈克·罗杰斯是麦卡锡的盟友，他必须;克制。盖茨最终成为;头目; 麦卡锡被罢免。

;;塞浦路斯承诺对违反制裁的行为采取“零容忍态度”，以捍卫其作为金融中心的地位.
;

;塞浦路斯誓言要加强对其金融部门的控制，《卫报》及其报道合作伙伴发布的一项调查显示，在俄罗斯入侵乌克兰后制裁迫在眉睫之际，寡头们转移了数亿资产。

;国际调查记者联盟 (ICIJ); 和德国 ;Paper Trail Media; >;，与卫报和其他报告合作伙伴共享访问权限。

;

;塞浦路斯有史以来最大的财务数据泄露事件也揭示了欧盟成员国会计师和企业服务提供商管理的不透明离岸结构可能如何影响允许向一位有影响力的西方记者进行未公开的付款，并可能违反足球俱乐部融资规则。

;

;塞浦路斯政府做出回应，承诺对违反制裁的行为采取“零容忍态度”，以捍卫其地位作为金融中心。

; ;

;在回答该财团的详细问题时，一位发言人表示，塞浦路斯正在接受英国政府的技术支持，将于明年建立一个制裁执行单位，计划于本月提交一份关于当局如何调查和起诉金融犯罪的报告。它还加入了一项旨在使制裁有效的欧盟跨境项目。

;

;针对普京以及与其政权关系密切的官员、政界人士和商界领袖实施制裁的时间和执行的确切规则目前正在接受审查，在塞浦路斯境内和欧洲各地。

;

;总统、总检察长、主要内阁成员和官员在上周的一次高级别会议上听取了有关该国实施更严格控制的进展情况的通报。塞浦路斯政府发言人康斯坦丁诺斯·莱廷比奥蒂斯 (Konstantinos Letymbiotis) 表示：“2023 年 3 月上任的我国政府的战略是对逃避制裁和违法行为采取零容忍态度，进而维护国家作为可靠金融国家的声誉。中心。我想强调的是，我国政府明确致力于打击腐败和非法金融，并采取一切必要行动，确保欧盟制裁得到全面实施。”

;

;此次泄密事件揭示了塞浦路斯作为进入欧盟的门户的作用规模。与克里姆林宫有联系的精英的欧洲。 《福布斯》杂志 2023 年确定的 104 名俄罗斯亿万富翁中，三分之二的人与家人一起成为岛上专业服务提供商的客户。有记录涉及自 2022 年 2 月以来受到制裁的 71 名俄罗斯客户。顾问称，其中许多关系已被终止。

;

;塞浦路斯机密文件显示：

;

;<普华永道塞浦路斯公司和其他顾问帮助俄罗斯最有权势的寡头之一阿列克谢·莫尔达肖夫 (Alexei Mordashov) 在受到欧盟制裁的当天试图转移其在一家上市公司的 10 亿英镑。 《卫报》获悉，这笔转账将在塞浦路斯接受“正在进行的”刑事调查。

;

;;•; 与同一寡头有关联的公司支付了 60 万欧元的未公开款项;致一位有影响力的德国记者;，他被认为是俄罗斯问题的领先专家，支持出版两本有关普京的书。

;

;;•; 罗曼·阿布拉莫维奇在拥有切尔西足球俱乐部期间向经纪人、球探和俱乐部官员支付了数千万美元的离岸款项，这些款项可能违反了规定会计和财务公平竞争方面严格的足球规则。

;

;;•; 未公开的协议允许阿布拉莫维奇和超级经纪人皮尼亚斯·扎哈维在有争议的第三方控制下控制 21 名年轻足球运动员的职业生涯所有权安排，类似于债役劳工。

;

;在就本报告联系塞浦路斯财政部后，该部表示已对 Mordashov 在欧洲最大的旅游运营商 Tui 的股份转让展开刑事调查。这位大亨的名字于 2022 年 2 月 28 日出现在欧盟制裁名单上，文件似乎显示他的顾问试图在同一天将他 10 亿英镑的股份转让给玛丽娜·莫达肖娃（Marina Mordashova），据报道她是他的终身伴侣。

;

;该部门的一位发言人表示：“我们知道途易股份转让，并且正在进行刑事调查。”

;

;途易是在伦敦和汉诺威证券交易所上市的最大公司之一，并且此次转让的细节约占公司股份的三分之一，已在 2022 年 3 月 4 日开始的股市文件中公布。

;

;Mordashov 的发言人表示，他和他的公司一直按照“公平的商业行为并严格遵守法规”。他们补充说：“与股份转让有关的所有信息和监管通知均在股份转让后不久就向有关当局适当披露并在法律要求的范围内公开，这清楚地表明没有隐瞒或规避的意图普华永道发言人表示：“任何不遵守适用法律和法规的指控都会得到非常严肃的对待，进行调查，并在必要时采取适当的行动。”

;

;莫达绍夫和普华永道表示，他们不知道刑事调查的情况。 《卫报》没有发现任何意图违反规则的证据。

;

;欧洲法院称，欧盟对莫尔达肖夫实施制裁的决定已于 9 月的判决得到确认，但寡头可以再次上诉.

;

;泄露的文件从 1990 年代中期到 2022 年 4 月，显示近 800 家在避税和保密天堂注册的公司和信托公司由俄罗斯人拥有或控制，自 2014 年以来一直受到制裁，当俄罗斯吞并克里米亚时。其中包括超过 650 家塞浦路斯公司和信托公司。

;

;今年 2 月当选总统的职业外交官尼科斯·赫里斯托杜利德斯 (Nikos Christodoulides) 在经历了数十年的宽松监管后，一直致力于使金融服务业恢复正常。

;

;今年春天，美国和英国对 23 名塞浦路斯护照持有人和十几家在塞浦路斯注册的公司实施制裁，其中包括离岸服务公司 MeritServus，他的政府开始加强对俄罗斯资本的控制。 ;《卫报》;协助阿布拉莫维奇在被列入制裁名单之前将其资产转移给家人。

;

;;乌克兰军队 10 月向巴赫穆特方向发射炮弹
;

;欧盟将错过其德国国防部长表示，德国国防部长表示，其目标是在明年 3 月之前向乌克兰提供 100 万枚炮弹和导弹。

;

;鲍里斯·皮斯托里斯 (Boris Pistorius) 的评论是欧洲高级部长首次公开承认该目标无法实现周三在布鲁塞尔举行的欧盟国防部长峰会之前做出的决定。

;

;“可以肯定的是，不会达到 100 万发子弹的目标，”皮斯托里斯说。几个月来，外交官和官员私下里一直对这一目标表示怀疑。

;

;该目标是为了满足乌克兰对 155 毫米炮弹的迫切和持续需求而设定的，155 毫米炮弹已成为其对抗俄罗斯入侵的关键要素因为冲突已经演变成一场激烈的消耗战。

;

;;今年早些时候，欧盟同意采取三管齐下的方法来增加供应;，因为乌克兰燃烧弹药的速度快于美国和北约的生产速度。

;

;欧盟的首席外交官何塞普·博雷尔 (Josep Borrell) 表示，国防部长“必须做得更多、更快”才能实现这一目标，据说这是完全可行的，但需要成员国紧急下达命令。

;

;“时间不仅是用基础设施和房屋的破坏来衡量的，也是用人的生命来衡量的，”他在布鲁塞尔举行的国防部长会议后告诉记者。

;

;博雷尔还表示，欧盟已提供了超过 30 万辆救灾物资。该计划的第一条轨道是炮弹和导弹，其中涉及欧盟成员国从自己的库存中交付。

;

;博雷尔表示，迫在眉睫的问题是欧盟以外的欧盟国防制造商的出口承诺。 “大约40%的产品出口到第三国，所以这并不是缺乏产能，”他说。

;

;“而是他们将产品发送到另一个市场。因此，也许我们要做的就是尝试将这种生产转移到优先生产的地方，即乌克兰。”他说。

;

;欧盟工业专员蒂埃里·布雷顿 (Thierry Breton) 表示，军​​火公司在增加产量，并且未来将欧洲 155 毫米炮弹产量提高到每年 100 万发的目标是可能的。

;

;“我可以确认，每年生产超过 100 万发弹药的目标我们为自己设定的目标以及他们希望从春季开始实现的目标将会得到实现。现在由成员国来下订单。 ”

;

;博雷尔表示，皮斯托利斯和布雷顿的声明都是正确的，一个提到了明年春天的目标，另一个提到了欧盟的能力。

;

;欧盟消息人士称弹药供应链到处“捉襟见肘”，但指出欧盟的产能比美国还要多。

;

;瑞典国防部长 Pål Jonson 表示，欧盟国防工业需要时间来增加供应。

; < p>;“在今天的欧洲，我们的国防工业是为了和平时期的情况，而不是为了欧洲发生大规模战争的情况，”他说。

;

;美国是乌克兰的最大支持者据追踪军事支持的;基尔研究所;称，德国、英国和挪威。

;

;根据议会;报告;显示，该国对乌克兰的军事支持费用已达到32 亿欧元（28 亿英镑）。

;

;德国政府数据;显示; 它已承诺从明年到 2027 年投入 105 亿欧元，其中 2022 年投入 20 亿欧元，2023 年投入 54 亿欧元。

;;路易斯·迪亚兹在巴兰基亚与父亲团聚。
;

;利物浦球员路易斯·迪亚兹已团聚与他的父亲一起，他于 10 月底在哥伦比亚北部被游击队的一个部队绑架，并于上周获释。

;

;哥伦比亚足协在 X（前身为 Twitter）帐户上发布的照片​​捕捉到了这名前锋，他的父亲路易斯·曼努埃尔·迪亚斯·希门尼斯互相拥抱。联合会以“欢迎卢胡回家”的消息宣布老迪亚兹抵达巴兰基亚，哥伦比亚国家队将于周四在那里对阵巴西队。

;

;骑摩托车的武装人员绑架了迪亚兹的父母。 10 月 28 日，巴兰卡斯小镇的一个加油站。他的母亲 Cilenis Marulanda 在数小时内被警察救出，警方在这座拥有 40,000 人的小镇周围设置了路障，该小镇位于哥伦比亚与委内瑞拉边境附近。

;

;绑架事件发生后，特种部队被派去搜寻迪亚兹的下落父亲在横跨哥伦比亚和委内瑞拉的山脉中。警方还悬赏提供线索的信息。

; ;

;最初并不清楚是谁实施了绑架。哥伦比亚政府随后宣布，其掌握的信息表明民族解放军（ELN）的一支部队对此负责。该组织后来承认了绑架事件，称这是一个错误，其最高领导层;下令释放父亲;。

;

;迪亚兹的父母在哥伦比亚政府与哥伦比亚政府之间的和平谈判期间被带走游击队。当局在周末逮捕了四名嫌疑人。

;

;哥伦比亚监察员办公室估计，2022 年 1 月至 2023 年 9 月期间，武装团体实施了 160 起绑架事件，并释放了 121 人。

;

;迪亚兹的父亲被释放后，政府的和平谈判代表团在一份声明中要求民族解放军立即释放其仍“囚禁”的任何人，并结束其绑架行为。“从道德角度来看，认为与人类进行贸易是合法的，这是不可持续的。” ，即使是在武装冲突的情况下，”声明中写道。

; Wed, 15 Nov 2023 02:52:01 +0800 ‘You’re finally free’: Matt LeBlanc pays tribute to Matthew Perryhttps://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2023/nov/14/youre-finally-free-matt-leblanc-pays-tribute-to-matthew-perry

;
;;勒布朗在他的 Instagram 页面上发布了一条令人心酸的消息，在马修·佩里去世两周多后向他告别。< /div>;

;马特·勒布朗向他已故的《老友记》联合主演马修·佩里致敬，称他的一些“最喜欢的时光”是和这位演员一起度过的。

;

;周二，两周多了佩里去世后，勒布朗在他的 Instagram 页面上发布了一条令人心酸的信息，向他的朋友告别。 56 岁的勒布朗在精选的美国情景喜剧中扮演乔伊·崔比亚尼和钱德勒·宾的照片中写道：“马修。我怀着沉重的心情告别。

;

;“老实说，我们在一起的时光是我一生中最喜欢的时光。很荣幸能与你同台，并称你为我的朋友。

;

;“当我想起你时，我会一直微笑，我永远不会忘记你。绝不。展开你的翅膀，飞吧，兄弟，你终于自由了。

;

;“非常的爱。我猜你还保留着欠我的 20 美元。”

;

;《老友记》演员勒布朗、大卫·休默、柯特妮·考克斯、丽莎·库卓和詹妮弗·安妮斯顿齐聚一堂 ;据美国报道，佩里于 11 月 3 日在森林草坪公墓举行葬礼;

;

;在向美国刊物《人物》发表的一份联合声明中，佩里的联合主演们表示，他们“彻底崩溃了”，并形容他们的关系“不仅仅是演员伙伴”。 “我们是一家人，”他们说。

;

;其他较小的演员在佩里去世后表达了哀悼。扮演钱德勒时断时续的女友贾妮丝·霍森斯坦的玛吉·惠勒在 Instagram 声明中表示，她感到“很幸运”能够与佩里一起度过充满创意的时刻。大卫（库卓在该剧的几集中扮演的菲比的爱人）在他的社交媒体上发布的视频中表示，他的“天才”朋友佩里帮助他清醒了。

;

; 2022 年，佩里出版了他的回忆录《朋友、恋人和可怕的大事》，其中他坦诚地谈论了如何应对毒瘾和酗酒的问题。马修·佩里基金会在这位明星去世后成立，以纪念他，承诺继续致力于“帮助其他与毒瘾作斗争的人”。

;

; Wed, 15 Nov 2023 02:52:01 +0800 One third of New Zealanders doubtful incoming coalition can work well together, poll findshttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/nov/15/new-zealand-election-results-coalition-poll-work-together
;;2023-11-14T18:00:43Z;
;
;;法案领袖 David Seymour（左）、即将上任的总理兼国家党领袖 Christopher Luxon 和新西兰优先党领袖 Winston Peters< /div>;

;投票给 ;新西兰的新领导层尚未转化为人们对即将上任的三党政府将进行建设性合作的广泛信心，而越来越多的人不确定该国是否走在正确的轨道上，新的《卫报》要点新西兰民意调查发现。

;

;在 ;最终选举结果;显示，中右翼国家党将要求自由主义法案和民粹主义的新西兰第一党组建政府.

;

;选举一个月后，随着即将上任的总理和国家党领导人之间的联合谈判，该国仍对政府将采取何种形式一无所知 ;Christopher Luxon;，法案领导人;大卫·西摩;和新西兰优先党领袖;温斯顿·彼得斯;继续拖下去。

;
;

;;相关：;;由于政府联盟谈判拖延，选举后一个月新西兰陷入困境;

;
;

;在最新的《卫报基本新西兰》民意调查中，37 % 的受访者表示，他们对三方能否开展建设性合作没有信心，而 31% 的受访者相信可以，32% 的受访者表示没有强烈的感觉。

; ;

;该民意调查还记录了不确定该国是否正在走向世界的人数有所增加方向正确——23%，高于 10 月份的 14%。近一半（48%）的人认为该国走在了错误的道路上，低于上个月的 57%； 29% 的人认为它走在正确的轨道上，与 10 月份的民意调查相比没有变化。

;

;虽然国家党和行动党是传统的联盟伙伴，但由资深议员 Peters 领导的新西兰优先党;可能会令人沮丧其他政党对其一些核心政策的雄心，包括国家党允许外国买家重返房地产市场的计划，以及国家党和法案希望大幅削减公共服务。

;

;民意调查受访者对于国家党是否会在其削减公共服务员工以减少政府支出的计划中取得正确的平衡，人们存在分歧——43%的人认为它不会达到正确的平衡，42%的人认为可以，另外15%的人不确定。

;

;与之前的民意调查结果类似，生活成本、经济、健康、确保公平税收和解决犯罪问题是受访者认为政党解决“非常重要”的前五个问题。

;

; >;

;当就国家党领导的政府可能对这些问题产生什么样的影响进行调查时，大多数人认为这将使经济、犯罪、税收和生活成本压力变得更好，但受访者认为国家党改善健康、解决住房危机和保护高危儿童的可能性较小。

;

;与此同时，只有 16% 的受访者认为即将上任的政府将缩小贫富差距，而 35% 的人认为这会加深分歧。在气候变化方面，17% 的人认为这会改善该问题的行动，23% 的人认为这会让事情变得更糟。

; ;

;There was an increase in the number of those polled who felt that overall, neither a Labour-led nor National-led government would make a real difference to the cost-of-living crisis – up to 53% in November compared with 43% in August's results.

;

;The Labour party experienced the worst defeat of a sitting government since the introduction of the country's mixed member proportional system in 1996, going from 65 seats in the 2020 election to 34 in 2023. Despite this, respondents were nearly evenly split in opinion over how much it had achieved during its time in office – 47% agreed it had achieved a lot or a fair amount, while 50% disagreed.

;

;But the desire for a change of leadership was underscored by how respondents felt about party leaders. Of the parties voted into parliament, ;Chris Hipkins; was the only leader to see a dip in popularity: 39% thought of him positively compared with 44% in October. Meanwhile, Luxon's popularity slightly increased from 33% prior to the election to 37% afterwards.

;

;;;•; This poll was conducted by Essential Research – a signatory to the New Zealand Political Polling Code – and has a sample size of 1,193, using quotas set to be representative of the target population by age, gender and location. Respondents not eligible or not intending to vote are excluded from voting questions. Weighting is applied to the data using factors of age, gender and location from Statistics New Zealand, and 2023 party vote from New Zealand Electoral Commission data. The poll was conducted through online panels between ;; 9;; and 12;; of November 2023, has a maximum margin of error of +/- 2.8%, a weighting efficiency of 90%. ;

; Wed, 15 Nov 2023 02:22:02 +0800 Édith Piaf’s voice re-created using AI so she can narrate own biopichttps://www.theguardian.com/music/2023/nov/14/edith-piaf-voice-recreated-using-ai-so-she-can-narrate-own-biopic
;;2023-11-14T17:32:45Z;
;
;;Édith Piaf performing in 1955.
;

;Sixty years after her death, Édith Piaf's voice will be re-created using AI to narrate her biopic.

;

;As ;reported by Variety;, Warner Music Group (WMG) has partnered with the Piaf estate to produce the feature-length film Edith. Artificial intelligence has been trained to replicate Piaf's voice by feeding it hundreds of voice clips, with WMG promising the resultant re-creation will “further enhance the authenticity and emotional impact of her story”.

;

;Animation will be used to provide “a modern take” on the La Vie en Rose singer's story, “while the inclusion of archival footage, stage and TV performances, personal footage and TV interviews will provide audiences with an authentic look at the significant moments of Piaf's life”. The French singer's original performances will also be used, with no announcement that the AI tech will be used to develop new music.

;

;The film is at a proof-of-concept stage, with WMG partnering with production company Seriously Happy to develop it further.

;

;Julie Veille, director of French documentaries on Diana Ross, Sting and Stevie Wonder, conceived it. “When creating the film, we kept asking ourselves, 'If Édith were still with us, what messages would she want to convey to the younger generations?'”, she said in a statement. “Her story is one of incredible resilience, of overcoming struggles and defying social norms to achieve greatness – and is as relevant now as it was then. Our goal is to utilise the latest advancements in animation and technology to bring the timeless story to audiences of all ages.”

;

;The executors of Piaf's estate, Catherine Glavas and Christie Laume, said: “It's been a special and touching experience to be able to hear Édith's voice once again – the technology has made it feel like we were back in the room with her. The animation is beautiful and through this film we'll be able to show the real side of Édith – her joyful personality, her humour and her unwavering spirit.”

;

;It's not the first time a dead artist has unexpectedly returned as a narrator: in 2022, Andy Warhol's voice was recreated via AI for Netflix documentary The Andy Warhol Diaries. His diary entries were read by actor Bill Irwin then morphed into Warhol's voice using the AI software programme Resemble, resulting in a 21st-century imagining of the robot version of himself that Warhol made in 1982.

;

;Actor Edward Herrmann became a celebrated audiobook narrator alongside roles in film and TV such as Annie and Gilmore Girls, and after his death in 2014, AI has been used to recreate his voice and allow him to narrate newly published audiobooks. His son has hailed the technology by London-based company DeepZen as “an amazing way to carry on his legacy”.

; ;

;The practice proved controversial when used in 2021 documentary ;Roadrunner: A Film About Anthony Bourdain;, about the late chef and documentarian Anthony Bourdain, who died in 2018. Director Morgan Neville used software trained on Bourdain's voice to recreate an email Bourdain had sent to a friend, with an ersatz Bourdain reflecting: “My life is sort of shit now. You are successful, and I am successful, and I'm wondering: Are you happy?”

;

;Morgan said that the audience ;wouldn't necessarily realise the sleight of hand;, saying: “If you watch the film … you probably don't know what the other lines are that were spoken by the AI, and you're not going to know.” Critics included Bourdain's ex-wife, Ottavia, who wrote: “I certainly was NOT the one who said Tony would have been cool with that.”

;

;In music, John Lennon's voice was recently isolated via AI software ;to help the surviving Beatles record Now and Then;, their final song together. Paul McCartney stressed that the software wasn't used to create a new Lennon performance: “Nothing has been artificially or synthetically created,” he said. “It's all real and we all play on it. We cleaned up some existing recordings.”

;

;But AI is increasingly being used to make entirely original performances by vocalists, whose voices are used to train AI software which then creates an accurate replication – and the artists themselves often object to it.

;

;In April, Drake said “this is the final straw” after an AI version of him was used in a fake performance of music by fellow rapper Ice Spice. That month Universal Music Group also complained of “infringing content created with generative AI”, and ;pulled a song from streaming services; that featured convincing AI-created versions of Drake and the Weeknd.

; Wed, 15 Nov 2023 01:52:02 +0800 Pro-Palestine protesters disrupt Canadian book prizehttps://www.theguardian.com/books/2023/nov/14/pro-palestine-protesters-disrupt-canadian-book-prize
;;2023-11-14T14:50:04Z;
;
;;A protester holding a sign saying 'Scotiabank Funds Genocide,' is escorted off the stage during the Scotiabank Giller Prize in Toronto.
;

;Pro-Palestine protesters twice interrupted the ceremony for a prestigious Canadian literary award held on Monday night.

;

;The event for the C$100,000 Scotiabank Giller prize was first disrupted when protesters jumped onstage with signs that read “Scotiabank funds genocide”. Event host Rick Mercer attempted to rip one of the signs from a protester's hands.

;

;;Video footage; shows another protester standing in the audience area shouting that Scotiabank “currently has a $500m stake in Elbit Systems” and that “Elbit Systems is supplying the Israeli military's genocide against the Palestinian people”.

;

;Elbit Systems is an Israel-based arms manufacturer that has ;long been criticised by activists; for supplying the Israeli military. In April, American investigative news outlet ;the Intercept reported; that Scotiabank's stake in the company was estimated to be $500m, making it the largest foreign shareholder.

;

;“We will not be silent any more,” a protester added. The group was quickly escorted out by police and later arrested, Giller spokesperson Robyn Mogil said, according to the Globe and Mail.

;

;The event was also interrupted as the winner's announcement was being made. Canadian author Sarah Bernstein won the prize for her novel Study for Obedience, which is also shortlisted for this year's Booker prize. As her name was called, a protester posing as a photographer began shouting, so the organisers repeated the announcement.

;

;The event comes just over a month after Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu declared war after the 7 October Hamas attack which killed 1,200 Israelis. Since then, more than 11,200 Palestinians have been killed, and in the past 10 days, 200,000 people ;have fled; northern Gaza.

;
;

;;Related: ;;'In the last four weeks language has deserted me': Adania Shibli on being shut down;

;
;

;Montreal-born Bernstein accepted the prize remotely from her home in the Scottish Highlands, where she had recently had a baby. In her video acceptance speech, she did not acknowledge the protests.

;

;Guests in attendance at the event included Margaret Atwood, who had previously won the prize. Other past winners include Michael Ondaatje, Alice Munro and Esi Edugyan, the chair of the 2023 Booker prize judging panel.

;

;Earlier this month, Canadian poet Rupi Kaur ;declined an invitation; to celebrate Diwali at the White House in protest at the US government's support of Israel's attacks on Gaza. In October, several countries and publishing associations ;pulled out of the Frankfurt book fair; after an awards ceremony celebrating Palestinian author Adania Shibli that was due to be held at the fair was called off.

;

;Scotiabank, the Giller prize and Elbit Systems did not respond to the Guardian's requests for comment.

; Tue, 14 Nov 2023 23:22:01 +0800 Spain’s People’s party urges EU to intervene over Catalan amnesty lawhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/nov/14/spain-peoples-party-urges-eu-to-intervene-over-catalan-amnesty-law
;;2023-11-14T15:18:53Z;
;
;;Law students at Madrid's Complutense University protest against the proposed amnesty deal for Catalan separatists
;

;Spain's conservative People's party (PP) has urged the EU to weigh in on the controversial Catalan amnesty law tabled by the ruling socialists, claiming it demands the kind of action the bloc has previously taken when concerns over the rule of law have arisen in ;Poland;, ;Hungary; and ;Romania;.

;

;The Spanish Socialist Workers' party (PSOE), which was narrowly beaten by the PP in ;July's inconclusive general election;, agreed to the amnesty after ;the two main Catalan pro-independence parties made it a condition; for supporting the formation of a new, socialist-led government with the support of a majority in parliament.

;

;The draft amnesty law would apply to hundreds of people involved in the unlawful push for Catalan independence between 2012 and last year. They include Carles Puigdemont, the former Catalan regional president who fled Spain to avoid arrest after masterminding ;the botched effort to secede in 2017;.

;

;Rightwing Spanish parties have accused Pedro Sánchez, the PSOE leader and caretaker prime minister, of debasing democracy and using the amnesty as a cynical ploy to remain in power. Around ;70% of Spanish voters are opposed;, and ;huge demonstrations against the move were held across Spain on Sunday;.

;

;The PP stepped up its attack on the proposed law as Spain's congress prepared for the investiture debate that is almost certain to result in Sánchez winning a new term in office on Thursday.

;

;The PP's leader, Alberto Núñez Feijóo, said Spain was facing “an unprecedented situation” and called on the EU to step in.

;

;“Tomorrow's investiture is a done deal … and the amnesty is a direct payment for the votes needed for the [PSOE] to form a government,” Feijóo told reporters in Madrid on Tuesday morning. “And who pays for that? The Spanish people, but also, in my opinion, Europe, because the deterioration of a democracy like Spain's … will obviously have consequences for European institutions.”

; ;

;He noted that the EU had intervened in the past when democratic norms and the rule of law had come under scrutiny in other member states. “It's done so in Poland, in Romania and in Hungary, and we think our case isn't radically different to those of those countries,” he said.

;

;Esteban González Pons, a PP MEP who also serves as the party's institutional vice-secretary, drew parallels with the EU's intervention in Romania four years ago.

;

;“The most similar case was ;in Romania in 2019; when a socialist government tried to bring in an amnesty law that would grant an amnesty to socialist politicians who had been convicted of corruption and other things,” he said. “When that happened, [the then European Commission president] Jean-Claude Juncker visited Bucharest and warned Romania that pressing on with the law could affect its position in the EU, and Romania agreed to a referendum on the issue, which it lost by 80% of the vote.”

;

;He also took the extreme step of likening the amnesty to the kind of legislation introduced during the fascist Franco dictatorship that lasted for almost four decades.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Spain is losing trust in politics. This backroom Catalan deal won't restore it;

;
;

;The law “declares a decade of impunity in Catalonia because all the crimes committed in Catalonia over the course of a decade will be covered by the amnesty, from terrorism to political corruption,” he said. “As such, anything that happens in other parts of Spain is a crime but anything can be forgiven in Catalonia. If you'll allow me to say so, this is the kind of law we saw during Francoism”.”

;

;The EU justice commissioner, Didier Reynders, has already written to the acting Spanish government asking for more details of the proposed law, saying the issue had raised serious concerns and had become “a matter of considerable importance in the public debate”.

;

;In a polite but blunt reply last week, the acting government pointed out that the Spanish constitution did not allow caretaker administrations to put legislation before parliament. Any such legislation, it said, would be proposed by political parties. It did, however, offer to provide more details to the commission once the amnesty bill had been tabled.

;

;Sánchez – who began negotiations to form a new government after ;Feijóo proved unable to do so, even with the support of the far-right Vox party and other smaller groupings; – has claimed the amnesty is needed to heal the wounds of the past and guarantee peaceful coexistence in Spain.

;

;He has also urged the PP to show “good sense” and cease trying to stir things up.

;

;“I ask them to respect the result at the ballot box and the legitimacy of the government we will soon form,” ;he said on Saturday;. “I ask them to be brave and to say no to the bear hug of the far right, and to abandon the reactionary path that they're currently following towards the abyss. We will govern for all Spaniards, for four more years of social progress and coexistence.”

; Tue, 14 Nov 2023 22:22:01 +0800 Hong Kong lecture by British barrister linked to Jimmy Lai trial cancelledhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/nov/14/hong-kong-lecture-by-british-barrister-linked-to-jimmy-lai-trial-cancelled
;;2023-11-14T13:26:23Z;
;
;;Timothy Owen
;

;A lecture in Hong Kong by the British barrister embroiled in a legal battle over whether he can represent the pro-democracy activist Jimmy Lai has been cancelled without explanation, raising concerns about the diminishing space for free speech in the semi-autonomous Chinese city.

;

;Timothy Owen KC was due to give a talk entitled “Judges, Democracy and the Criminal Law” at the University of Hong Kong (HKU) on 17 November. But on Tuesday, the lecture was cancelled without explanation,; ;with the university citing “unforeseen circumstances”. The website for the law faculty appears to be offline.

;

;The talk was co-hosted with Boase Cohen & Collins, a local law firm. Last month, in ;an article advertising the talk;, Colin Cohen, a senior partner, said he was “thrilled” that Owen had accepted the firm's invitation to deliver the lecture, adding: “We are certain that his talk will be hugely popular with a large cross-section of the legal profession and the general public.” The link to register for the talk is no longer active.

;

;The talk had been advertised as a discussion of “the growing threats to judicial independence and the rule of law with particular focus on the administration of criminal justice”.

;

;HKU declined to elaborate on the reason for the cancellation. Boase Cohen & Collins have been approached for comment. Owen declined to comment.

;

;Owen has clashed with the authorities over his ability to represent Lai in his national security trial.

;

;Lai, 75, is charged with colluding with foreign forces under the city's national security law, charges the ;British government describes as “highly politicised”;.

;

;In November 2022, Hong Kong's top court ruled that Owen could defend Lai in the trial, despite multiple objections from the territory's Department of Justice.

;

;Hong Kong's chief executive, John Lee, then asked Beijing to intervene, prompting an ;“interpretation” of Hong Kong's national security law; to clarify that foreign lawyers could not work on national security cases without approval from the city's chief executive, or head of government.

;

;This interpretation was later enshrined into Hong Kong's law, with the authorities ;using that new power to block Owen from Lai's case; in May. Lai's legal team is appealing against that decision.

;

;The cancellation of Owen's talk at HKU comes after a number of incidents that have raised concerns about academic freedom in the Chinese territory.

;

;In October, it emerged that Rowena He, a Canadian historian who researches the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre, had been fired from her post as an associate professor at the Chinese University of Hong Kong, after the city's immigration authorities declined to extend her visa.

;

;Last year, Ryan Thoreson, a US human rights scholar who had previously worked at Human Rights Watch, was denied a visa to teach human rights law at HKU. No explanation was given.
